content:
ASIA-PAC

New Zealand GDT Price Change -0.6% (Prev. -1.2%) and Wholemilk Powder Price Change 1.6% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires)

BoJ Governor Kuroda said the bank is internally discussing an exit from current monetary policy but will not communicate it with the markets until policy normalising timing draws near. (Newswires)

Italian President Mattarella is said to be unlikely to give PM mandate during this week. (Newswires)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 55.1 vs. Exp. 54.8 (Prev. 55.2, Rev. 55.0). (Newswires)
EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Mar) 56.6 vs. Exp. 56.6 (Prev. 56.6)

FX

While in recent weeks USD strength has come hand-in-hand with risk-off sentiment, the USD managed to modestly rally on Tuesday amid a more constructive risk environment. Perhaps the buck was following Treasury yields higher (although major curve spreads actually flattened), or perhaps it was the rise in TIPS yields. Or perhaps it was due to softer Eurozone PMIs, keeping the single currency under pressure. The backed-off the 1.23 level that was proving magnetic in recent trade after stops were tripped around 1.2280, seeing EURUSD find lows around 1.2260. The net impact was GBP seeing some upside against the EUR, and less so against the USD. CAD found strength following positive NAFTA headlines on Monday, sending the Loonie to test the bottom-end of its recent range; the 1.28 level was breached, but USDCAD managed to bring its head back above the level. High-beta FX also benefited from the better risk tone.


COMMODITIES

US API Weekly Crude Inventories (29 Mar) -3.280M vs. Exp. 0.200M (Prev. 5.321M). (Newswires)

Russian Energy Minister Novak stated he has discussed long-term oil co-operation with Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih, while he added that a potential creation of an OPEC/non-OPEC organisation was also discussed. (Newswires)

OPEC Q1 2018 oil production rates represent a 425k BPD decline from the average daily supply for 2017 and OPEC 14 oil supply fell in Q1 2018 to 32.27mln BPD, according to Petro Logistics. (Newswires)


US

Fed’s Brainard (Voter, Dove) said financial asset valuations are stretched with cyclical pressures building and noted that asset prices may be vulnerable to outside economic shock. Brainard further commented that US trade policy is a material uncertainty for the economic outlook, while she added that gradual rate hikes are appropriate and that US fiscal stimulus as well as other tailwinds could help to re-anchor inflation at 2%. (Newswires)  

New York Fed has selected San Francisco Fed President John Williams to be next president and succeed William Dudley on June 18th. (Newswires)

US issued list of products from China proposed for tariffs with the list covering around 1300 tariff lines and which will be under further review. Furthermore, reports also noted that US tariff list on China products include aerospace, marine parts, telecoms equipment and medical devices. (Newswires)

US President Trump estimated that the cost of intellectual property theft to the US amounts to between USD 200bln-300bln per year and said that he has respect for China President Xi, but has a problem with the US trade deficit with China. (Newswires)

US President Trump is said to discuss reducing part of the spending deal, according to Twitter sources citing CNBC. (Twitter/CNBC)

US President Trump's infrastructure policy adviser Gribbin is to leave the White House. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

US Equity futures traded sideways pre-market which initially continued in market hours with a wider range. The SPX’s 200dma – which had been a strong support through the slides earlier this year – was the focal point of price action, before stocks climbed in later trade after news that the White House is not holding talks regarding action against Amazon (AMZN), which saw other major indices rise in sympathy. Additionally, ahead of the upcoming Q2 earnings season, analysts are optimistic on the outlook. In stock specific news, Viacom (VIAB) weighed on the SPX & NDX following reports that CBS (CBS) is considering an all stock offer for the company which values them under its current market valuation. Tesla (TSLA) led the NDX higher on Tuesday, rebounding some of the stocks previous losses on reports that Q1 production was up 40% Q/Q, with 2020 Model 3 vehicles being made within the last 7 days, and it expects this trend to carry on in the next week. Further, it stated by addressing bottlenecks Model 3 production rate will be able to double this quarter. SPX +1.27% at 2614 , NDX +1.06% at 6459, DJI +1.63% at 24030.

Yields along the Treasury curve are higher on Tuesday by between 3.5bps and 5bps, with most of the moves being seen in the belly of the curve. Major curve spreads only saw modest steepening, however, remain only slightly of recent narrows. Volume was slightly better on Tuesday’s subdued showing. Most of the action was centred around the European and US opens, where large block trades in TYM8 catalysed selling pressures, while sellers were also encouraged by better risk sentiment, equities rebounding, and a few chunky corporate issuance announcements, while vehicle sales beats from the Big Three manufacturers also was being cited. Some note that the TPLEX will take its cue from inflation headlines in the weeks/months ahead (absent any haven bid), and as such, attention moves towards NFP data at the end of the week (specifically wages) as well as comments due from Fed Chair Powell on Friday. US T-Notes (June) settled 13+ ticks lower at 120-27.

Oil was supported by better risk sentiment and positive news flow, shrugging-off the USD strength seen in flashes over the course of the session. Russia said it will trim oil production levels in early April after yesterday’s news that it pumped 10.97mln BPD in March, overtaking the US to take the mantle as the world’s largest producer. Russian energy minister Novak also alluded to the possible creation of an amalgamated OPEC/non-OPEC organisation, as has been floated by others recently. Elsewhere, According to Petro Logistics, OPEC Q1 output has fallen to the lowest level since the beginning of the supply cut deal, with production in Q1 425k fewer than the average daily supply for 2017 as a whole. In Norway, the largest labour union has threatened industrial action, potentially seeing 37k oil workers strike. After the bell, API will report energy inventories for the week. The Street expects headline crude stocks to build by 200k, distillate stocks are seen drawing by 1.1mln barrels, and gasoline stocks are seen declining by 1.3mln barrels.

PREVIEW: Eurozone HICP (March, flash) will be released on 4 April at 1000 BST/0500 EDT
content:
Analysts expect headline HICP to come in at 1.4% (range 1.2% to 1.5%, prior 1.1%); HICP ex food/energy seen at 1.3% (range 1.2% to 1.4%, prior 1.2%) and HICP ex food/energy/alcohol/tobacco to print a reading of 1.1% (range 1.0% to 1.3%, prior 1.0%).  

Credit Suisse believes a rise to 1.4% in March will be lead by higher core inflation as well as positive food and energy price base effects. However, Commerzbank sees greater upside, forecasting an increase to 1.5% due to calendar effects, as the Easter break may have buoyed prices for holidays, while weather effects (cold March), and a rise in energy prices may also support.  

Commerzbank expects inflation to rise to 2% in the summer, however, the ECB only expect inflation to rise to 1.4% in 2018. In the middle of March, ECB President Draghi said he wants to see further evidence that inflation is moving towards target (close to, but below 2%), noting underlying inflation pressures remain subdued compared to previous recoveries, and that there are still risks. Draghi also said it will be a requisite for inflation to sustainably move to target as a condition for exiting QE.

Daily FX Wrap: Dollar on course for decent session and firmer foothold above 90.000
content:
Some choppy trade, especially during the EU am session through manufacturing PMIs and some contrast CB commentary on the face of it, but the Greenback looks set to claw back losses vs some G10 rivals and the DXY back over 90.000.

CAD/NZD/AUD

The commodity block continues to buck the broader trend of losing ground vs the Usd, with the Loonie now rivalling the Kiwi as top performer as positive NAFTA impulses combine with technical to drive Usd/Cad down towards major layered support ahead of the 1.2800 handle, while Nzd/Usd probed above 0.7250 as the Aud/Nzd cross lost grip of the 1.0600 big figure again – Aud not deriving any independent impetus from a still very neutral RBA overnight, albeit adding concerns about global trade wars and also eyeing a hefty 1.1 bn expiry at 0.7680, almost bang in the middle of the 0.7705-0.7650 wide range. Note, no Nzd reaction to very mixed GDT auction prices.

GBP  

Unable to sustain gains made on the back of a firmer than forecast UK manufacturing PMI as stops were triggered at 1.4060 and 1.4050 as the 100 HMA at 1.4057 gave way (low 1.4020).

EUR

Also the victim of stops after its 30 DMA (1.2322) was breached to the downside with sell-orders touted on a break of 1.2280, but more at 1.2250 not yet tripped and chart support at 1.2240 respected accordingly.

JPY

The weakest major and down almost 100 pips vs the Usd from best levels seen on Easter Monday (to 106.55 from 105.66) after a fleeting lift on BoJ QQE exit talk from Governor Kuroda (but only in theory at this stage as part of internal feasibility studies).

DAILY US OPENING NEWS: European bourses are lower after losses on Wall St. and Asia overnight (Eurostoxx -0.9%) as Chinese trade retaliation and tech woes weighed heavily across the bourses.
content:
3rd April 2018

  • European bourses are lower after losses on Wall St. and Asia overnight (Eurostoxx -0.9%) as Chinese trade retaliation and tech woes weighed heavily across the bourses.
  • The broad Dollar remains on the back foot amidst heighted US vs China tit-for-tat import tariff impositions, but off worst levels vs G10 and other major counterparts.
  • Looking ahead, highlights include APIs and Fed’s Kashkari

ASIA

Asian stocks were mostly lower as the downbeat tone rolled over from Wall St where China’s trade retaliation and tech woes weighed heavily across all bourses, with losses in the S&P 500 (-2.2%) exacerbated on technical selling after a break below the 200DMA while the Nasdaq underperformed as it slipped into the red YTD and into correction territory. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) both opened lower with the latter suffering the brunt of a firmer currency and with losses seen across tech names following similar underperformance in their US counterparts, which was led by selling in Amazon after President Trump’s tirade on the online giant. Conversely, Australian stocks then recovered as mining stocks and energy names outperformed. Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) conformed to the tech-related losses and after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations for an 8th consecutive occasion, while markets in Hong Kong also took their 1st opportunity to react to China’s tariffs on US products and reports of the government pressuring banks to halt local government lending. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as they tracked the prior session’s gains in T-notes amid the risk-averse tone, while the 10yr JGB auction results were inconclusive with the results mixed as the b/c fell but accepted prices surged from prior.

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB's Liikanen has emerged as a potential compromise candidate for the ECB President role. (FT)

BoJ Governor Kuroda said the bank is internally discussing an exit from current monetary policy but will not communicate it with the markets until policy normalising timing draws near. He added the BoJ will patiently continue easing of current monetary policy as there is still a distance to the price target. (Newswires)

RBA kept the Cash Rate Target unchanged at 1.50% as expected and reiterated that steady policy is consistent with growth and inflation goals. RBA also repeated that a strengthening currency would result to slower pace of economic pick-up but that the currency remains in the range seen prior years, while it also commented that inflation likely to stay low for some time. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (Mar) 56.6 vs. Exp. 56.6 (Prev. 56.6) (Newswires)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 55.1 vs. Exp. 54.8 (Prev. 55.2, Rev. 55.0)

EQUITIES

European bourses have opened lower after losses on Wall St. and Asia overnight (Eurostoxx -0.9%), Chinese trade retaliation and tech woes weighed heavily across the bourses. The tech sell-off rolled over from the previous sessions with the sector currently underperforming. Semi-conductors are amongst the worst performers as names take a hit on the news that Apple is looking to steer away from Intel chips to create their own by 2020. On the flip side, Barclays was initially higher after reports the bank is planning a multi-million GBP share buyback. Miners are amongst the top performers after feeling the boost from firmer base metal prices. Finally, Sky (+1.3%) is at the top of the FTSE 100 amid news that Fox is offering to sell Sky News to Disney as it seeks to obtain regulatory clearings for its proposed takeover of Sky.

FX

DXY

The broad Dollar remains on the back foot amidst heighted US vs China tit-for-tat import tariff impositions, but off worst levels vs G10 and other major counterparts to leave the Index close to the 90.000 mark within a 89.850-90.070 approximate range.

JPY

One of the more lively currencies as EU markets return from their extended Easter break amidst some mixed and contradictory comments from BoJ Governor Kuroda (at least in terms of the wire headline interpretations). He initially underscored easy policy guidance and appeared to quell any speculation about an exit given that inflation is still some distance from target, but then revealed that internal discussions about unwinding the balance sheet and raising rates are underway, though nothing will be communicated to the markets until such time that economic growth and prices are right. Usd/Jpy fell abruptly from just above 106.00 towards the 105.70 low before rebounding to around 106.20 and a slightly higher peak vs yesterday’s 105.66 base.

NZD/AUD

The top G10 performers as commodities show some signs of stabilisation amidst less risk-off sentiment vs recent sessions, with Nzd/Usd probing 0.7250 again and Aud/Usd not far from 0.7700 despite no surprises at all from the RBA overnight (maintained OCR and essentially all elements of a neutral statement with inflation still expected to take time to pick up). Back to the Kiwi, eyes on the latest GDT auction after a period of declining prices that have effectively reversed the squeeze earlier in 2018 on weather-related factors. Note that the Aud/Nzd cross is back down near 1.0600 have traded above 1.0650 overnight.

CAD (and MXN)

The Loonie is gleaning support from latest NAFTA reports suggesting that US President Trump is keen on nailing down a deal by the middle of the month, with Usd/Cad back under 1.2900.

GBP

Cable is extending gains above 1.4050 towards 1.4100 and Eur/Gbp is looking at bids/support around 0.8750 in wake of a firmer than forecast UK manufacturing PMI and amidst UK press reports claiming that PM May is looking at a customs partnership as a resolution for the Irish border.

EUR

Eur/Usd is back above 1.2300 after mixed Eurozone national manufacturing PMIs left the pan print unchanged from the preliminary reading, and with little real reaction to an FT story putting Liikanen in pole spot to replace Draghi as next head of the ECB.

FIXED INCOME

A bit more range extension and a pick-up in trading volumes as core EU debt gradually reacclimatise after the 4-day Easter closure. Gilts continue to outperform or rather hold up better between 122.75-123.00 Liffe parameters despite a better than anticipated UK manufacturing PMI vs mixed Eurozone releases that ultimately left the pan unchanged from the flash estimate. As noted earlier, respective closing times look to be partially at play in terms of Bunds lagging their UK equivalent or vice-versa, but technicals also appeared to exacerbate the sell-off in 10 year German and other EZ paper (like stocks, but in the sector sense of course). Indeed, market contacts noted stops on a break of 159.12, but bigger sell-orders if 159.05 is breached vs the 159.07 current low (-36 ticks vs -7 ticks for Gilts at the Liffe low), while Bonos seem to be heeding some cautious comments from the Bank of Spain on the public finance outlook. Elsewhere, US Treasuries continue to unwind recent safe-haven gains even though EU equities are succumbing to more intense selling pressure after displaying a degree of resistance earlier.

COMMODITIES

In the commodities bloc, oil prices posted gains despite Russia’s production for March climbing to 10.97mln bpd making the country the largest oil producer in the world. Prices also held gains, ignoring potential reductions in Saudi Arabian oil prices. Gold prices inched lower, despite softer equities which continued to sell-off. Elsewhere, profit taking sent Chinese steel futures lower for the first time in six trading sessions. London copper hits its highest level in more than a week, lifted by better than expected Chinese manufacturing PMIs.

subject: PREVIEW: Fonterra GDT Dairy Auction - futures indicate a circa 1% fall in WMP prices
content:
The most recent auction saw the headline GDT price index fall by 1.2% to USD 3,632, while whole milk powder prices rose by 0.1% to Usd 3,226.

 

While futures indicate that WMP prices could fall as much as 1% today as supply conditions improve, the usual margin of error and an upgrade in price projections could result in another flattish reading and more consolidation.

 

Although there is no set time for release, auction results typically are released from 14:00GMT.

subject: EU MID-SESSION UPDATE: European equities extending losses amid trade tensions and growing concerns over the tech sector
content:
EQUITIES

European bourses have opened lower after losses on Wall St. and Asia overnight (Eurostoxx -0.9%), Chinese trade retaliation and tech woes weighed heavily across the bourses. The tech sell-off rolled over from the previous sessions with the sector currently underperforming. Semi-conductors are amongst the worst performers as names take a hit on the news that Apple is looking to steer away from Intel chips to create their own by 2020. On the flip side, Barclays (+0.2%) is higher after reports the bank is planning a multi-million GBP share buyback. Miners are amongst the top performers after feeling the boost from firmer base metal prices. Finally, Sky (+0.9%) is at the top of the FTSE 100 amid news that Fox is offering to sell Sky News to Disney as it seeks to obtain regulatory clearings for its proposed takeover of Sky.

FX

DXY

The broad Dollar remains on the back foot amidst heighted US vs China tit-for-tat import tariff impositions, but off worst levels vs G10 and other major counterparts to leave the Index close to the 90.000 mark within a 89.850-90.070 approximate range.

JPY

One of the more lively currencies as EU markets return from their extended Easter break amidst some mixed and contradictory comments from BoJ Governor Kuroda (at least in terms of the wire headline interpretations). He initially underscored easy policy guidance and appeared to quell any speculation about an exit given that inflation is still some distance from target, but then revealed that internal discussions about unwinding the balance sheet and raising rates are underway, though nothing will be communicated to the markets until such time that economic growth and prices are right. Usd/Jpy fell abruptly from just above 106.00 towards the 105.70 low before rebounding to around 106.20 and a slightly higher peak vs yesterday’s 105.66 base.

NZD/AUD

The top G10 performers as commodities show some signs of stabilisation amidst less risk-off sentiment vs recent sessions, with Nzd/Usd probing 0.7250 again and Aud/Usd not far from 0.7700 despite no surprises at all from the RBA overnight (maintained OCR and essentially all elements of a neutral statement with inflation still expected to take time to pick up). Back to the Kiwi, eyes on the latest GDT auction after a period of declining prices that have effectively reversed the squeeze earlier in 2018 on weather-related factors. Note that the Aud/Nzd cross is back down near 1.0600 have traded above 1.0650 overnight.

CAD (and MXN)

The Loonie is gleaning support from latest NAFTA reports suggesting that US President Trump is keen on nailing down a deal by the middle of the month, with Usd/Cad back under 1.2900.

GBP

Cable is extending gains above 1.4050 towards 1.4100 and Eur/Gbp is looking at bids/support around 0.8750 in wake of a firmer than forecast UK manufacturing PMI and amidst UK press reports claiming that PM May is looking at a customs partnership as a resolution for the Irish border.

EUR

Eur/Usd is back above 1.2300 after mixed Eurozone national manufacturing PMIs left the pan print unchanged from the preliminary reading, and with little real reaction to an FT story putting Liikanen in pole spot to replace Draghi as next head of the ECB.

FIXED INCOME

A bit more range extension and a pick-up in trading volumes as core EU debt gradually reacclimatise after the 4-day Easter closure. Gilts continue to outperform or rather hold up better between 122.75-123.00 Liffe parameters despite a better than anticipated UK manufacturing PMI vs mixed Eurozone releases that ultimately left the pan unchanged from the flash estimate. As noted earlier, respective closing times look to be partially at play in terms of Bunds lagging their UK equivalent or vice-versa, but technicals also appeared to exacerbate the sell-off in 10 year German and other EZ paper (like stocks, but in the sector sense of course). Indeed, market contacts noted stops on a break of 159.12, but bigger sell-orders if 159.05 is breached vs the 159.07 current low (-36 ticks vs -7 ticks for Gilts at the Liffe low), while Bonos seem to be heeding some cautious comments from the Bank of Spain on the public finance outlook. Elsewhere, US Treasuries continue to unwind recent safe-haven gains even though EU equities are succumbing to more intense selling pressure after displaying a degree of resistance earlier.

COMMODITIES

In the commodities bloc, oil prices posted gains despite Russia’s production for March climbing to 10.97mln bpd making the country the largest oil producer in the world. Prices also held gains, ignoring potential reductions in Saudi Arabian oil prices. Gold prices inched lower, despite softer equities which continued to sell-off. Elsewhere, profit taking sent Chinese steel futures lower for the first time in six trading sessions. London copper hits its highest level in more than a week, lifted by better than expected Chinese manufacturing PMIs.

subject: JPM on Equities: Look for equities to stabilise soon
content:
• Eurozone to keep bottoming out vs the US as US tailwinds fade (Tech, earnings, USD)
  • Italy stays our top pick
  • Stay underweight UK
  • Overweight financials and underweight defensives, apart from continental non-regulated Utilities (Overweight)
  • Headwinds for Technology sector and Mining are increasing

 

JPM believes that risk-reward for stocks has not turned medium term negative, and we would be adding at these levels:

1) Equities again entered oversold territory at end-March, with MXWO RSI touching 30. In contrast, JPM thinks bonds are close to being overbought. Investor sentiment is not complacent anymore, with worries ranging from growth to liquidity to valuations, which JPM says is a healthy development. Positioning is less stretched – HF beta is back to its historical range.

2) The complacency over growth outlook appears to be correcting, as PMIs turned lower and with trade uncertainty dominating. JPM does not think that growth necessarily needs to downshift sharply; beyond some stalling, there is no obvious imbalance in the drivers of end-demand which needs to be corrected. The pace of growth is likely to remain above trend. Eurozone CESI is not far from 2016 lows and should bounce from here, JPM believes. April PMIs could arrest the recent decline as negative weather impact drops out. Key US data – claims, confidence and ISM – remains encouraging.

3) Earnings to stay a support, with Q1 reporting season to be taken well, JPM says. Even post some stalling, Q1 activity levels are still stronger than they were in Q4, while in contrast Q1 consensus EPS expectations (ex-tax) are much more muted than they were in Q4, with median Euro area projection at only 5% YY for Q1. JPM notes though that the bulk of the EPS upgrades on the back of the US tax cuts are by now behind us.

4) Despite persistent concerns, bond yields are still within past ranges, and central bank tightening is still in its early stages, with US real policy rates continuing to be outright negative. None of the last eight downturns started with real rates lower than 2%. Classic end-of-cycle indicators are not flashing warnings signs, yet. The yield curve is flattening, but it is unlikely to get inverted until at least 2H 2018. Crucially, stocks have never peaked before the yield curve inverted.

5) Relative to fixed income, JPM finds equity valuations remain undemanding and continue to offer a substantial valuation gap vs historical averages. JPM thinks bond yields should keep repricing higher this year, but its core view is that equities should be able to tolerate rising yields, as we are not yet reaching the yield levels that would be detrimental to valuation multiples or to the sustainability of the economic cycle.

The tailwinds behind the US vs Eurozone outperformance (Tech, earnings, USD) to continue fading; Remain UW UK and Switzerland, JPM says.

- OW Eurozone: Eurozone equities are ytd outperforming the US ones, in USD, and JPM expects this to continue. The bank thinks that most of the positive EPS impact from US tax cuts is by now behind us, and that USD could stabilise near term, which should help Eurozone. Further, the region benefits from rising yields given its Value tilt and Eurozone P/E multiples look cheaper again. In contrast, Technology might become a relative drag on the US. Within Eurozone, JPM favours periphery over core. Italy remains JPM's top pick and we would use any potential politics-induced volatility as a buying opportunity.

- OW Japan: The policy divergence between BoJ and the RoW should translate into higher Japanese equities, JPM says. Robust domestic activity helps earnings, Japan would benefit from a further rise in global yields and Japanese valuations appear attractive.

- Neutral EM: JPM was OW EM in 2016 and in 2017, but believes the region might show some consolidation vs DM this year. Of course, if USD keeps falling, then this would be a positive for EM, the bank argues. On the other side, JPM worries that EM might struggle if the US political agenda moves strongly anti-trade or if China activity slows, and JPM notes bullish China view appears consensus. The bank believes that Tech might start to consolidate its dramatic outperformance, which could be another headwind for the EM. Finally, if there is a sharp repricing of bond yields, EM might be under relative pressure as carry trades are unwound. This is especially because EMBI index received record inflows last year, of 125bn USD. JPM sees this as a tactical call, rather than as a fundamental change of direction, and believes the EM backdrop still looks attractive over the medium term: 1) Fed tightening is not a concern, by itself; looking at the last four Fed tightening cycles, EM outperformed in three. 2) the EM-DM growth differential is bottoming out, after five years of disappointments. 3) EM valuations look attractive at 12x fwd P/E – a 30% discount to DM.

- UW UK: UK is a defensive, high-dividend yielding market which might have a problem if bond yields move sustainably higher. Growth-Policy trade-off looks poor for the UK, with higher rates and inflation, but softer activity. A stronger GBP is a problem for FTSE100 as it derives close to 70% of revenues from abroad.

subject: Short Sterling futures flat to 1 tick firmer, Gilts 'outperforming' core debt peers
content: Modest flattening across the 3 month UK STIR strip in line with broad risk aversion over the long Easter weekend, while Gilts have returned to Liffe on the front foot within a 122.82-123.00 range vs the 122.82 previous despite more erosion of the initial/early safe-haven bid in Bunds that have now retreated to a 159.14 Eurex low (-29 ticks vs +18 ticks at one stage). Relative closing times are impacting the divergent price action/moves ahead of the UK manufacturing PMI that should or at leas could provide some independent direction, while the core debt future will also be eyeing the first of this week’s BoE buy-back auctions (15+ years) before the DMO releases size details for the upcoming 1.75% 2057 supply.

content: Catch-up trade off the Eurex open, and an initial 14 tick mark-up before some modest follow-through buying to an early 159.61 peak vs last Thursday’s 159.43 close on broad risk-off flows. However, the 10 year German benchmark has not sustained gains and is drifting all the way back down to just under parity at 159.41 in the run up to the start of EU cash bourse trade with futures indicating losses, but not perhaps as severe as might have been expected given the scale of losses seen on Wall Street yesterday. Ahead, Eurozone manufacturing PMIs are due, but unlikely to prompt a major market reaction as bonds continue to take their cues from broader sentiment.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from GKN/Melrose, Barclays, AstraZeneca/Shire and many more
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

3rd April 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia stocks were mostly lower as the downbeat tone rolled over from Wall St where China’s trade retaliation and tech woes weighed heavily across all bourses, with losses in the S&P 500 (-2.2%) exacerbated on technical selling after a break below the 200DMA while the Nasdaq underperformed as it slipped into the red YTD and into correction territory. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) both opened lower with the latter suffering the brunt of a firmer currency and with losses seen across tech names following similar underperformance in their US counterparts, which was led by selling in Amazon after President Trump’s tirade on the online giant. Conversely, Australian stocks then recovered as mining stocks and energy names outperformed. Hang Seng (-0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.9%) conformed to the tech-related losses and after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations for an 8th consecutive occasion, while markets in Hong Kong also took their 1st opportunity to react to China’s tariffs on US products and reports of the government pressuring banks to halt local government lending.

FTSE

GKN (GKN LN)/Melrose (MRO LN) – The UK government has warned that it could block Melrose’s takeover of GKN (GKN LN) on public interest grounds after shareholders voted to approve the deal by a narrow margin. (Times)

AstraZeneca (AZN LN) / Shire (SHP LN) – Co.’s made millions of pounds of “secret” payments to healthcare professionals and organisations. A minimum of EUR 22.3mln was made in anonymous payments across Europe; including EUR 17.9mln by AstraZeneca and EUR 4.4mln by Shire. (The Times)

Rolls Royce (RR/ LN) – Co. relaxed the lobbying restrictions on its largest shareholder, which reports state raises the possibility of a break up. (Times)

Barclays (BARC LN) – Co. is planning a multimillion-GBP share buyback after last week’s settlement of claims that it mis-sold sub-prime loans in the run-up to the financial crisis. (Times) Additionally, the Co. is the first among UK banks to have completed ring fencing in which its investment bank was separated from the retail operations. (Newswires)

easyJet (EZJ LN) – Co. CEO said they are prepared to take place in sector consolidation. (Newswires)

HSBC (HSBA LN) – Co. is to pay USD 100mln to settle antitrust claims regrading Libor and OTC investors. (Newswires)

Anglo American (AAL LN) – The Brazilian environmental regulators ordered the Co. to suspend operations in the country after a pipeline leakage. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

TalkTalk (TALK LN) – The co. is being urged to improve its cybersecurity in wake of worryingly easy web system flaw. (Sky)

BBA Aviation (BBA LN) – Co. hired Lazard for sale of its engine repair and overhaul division seen to be valued at GBP 300mln. (Times)

Vedanta Resources (VED LN) – Co. may have to take a USD 500-600mln charge net of taxes on their Iron Ore Goa mine. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) – A prominent shareholder in the Co. urges investors to vote against re-electing Wolfgang Porsche as a member of the Co.’s supervisory board at its annual general meeting. (Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SIEMENS (SIE GY) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT VERTICAL RESEARCH

CAC

Euronext (ENX FP) – CEO states that the Co.’s acquisition of the Irish stock exchange was part of a broader plan to draw companies that might be rethinking their London listings in light of Brexit. (FT)

Total (FP FP) - CEO sees revenue growth of around 5% over the next 5 years. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Air France (AF FP) – Co. pilot unions called for a fresh round of strikes to be conducted on April 10-11th to add to the already planned strikes for April 3rd and 7th. (Euronews)

BROKER MOVES

SODEXO (SW FP) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT NATIXIS

PAN-EUROPE

Intesa Sanpaolo (ISP IM) – CEO states that the Co. is planning to merge its asset management unit with that of another bank. (FT)

AB InBev (ABI BB) – Co. recalls packs of Stella Artois “Best of Belgium” in US and Canada. (Newswires)

Mediaset (MS IM) – Co. signed a content-sharing deal with Sky’s (SKY LN) Italian unit. The deal could lead to a revenue increase of up to EUR 80mln to EUR 100mln for the next three to five years for Mediaset. (Corriere della Sera)

Gemalto (GTO NA) – Executives from De La Rue (DLAR LN) are set to challenge British high courts against the government’s decision to allow Co. to produce new blue national passports from 2019. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

US

EQUITIES: SPX -2.3% at 2580, DJIA -2.0% at 23,629, NDX -2.9% at 6391;

SECTORS: Utilities -1.2%, Telecoms -1.6%, Energy -2.5%, Healthcare -2.6%, Consumer non-cyclicals -2.6%, Financials -2.6%, Materials -2.7%, Industrials -2.7%, Tech -3.0%, Consumer Cyclicals -3.3%

With Europe, UK, Australia, New Zealand and Canada on a market holiday, liquidity was thin, and price action was choppy, amid the risk-off tone begotten by a perceived escalation of Trade Wars by China overnight, where it announced it would apply tariffs of up to 25% on imports of US pork, wine, and nuts (many analysts have downplayed the impact, though the likes of Tyson Foods were hit on the news). Equity futures were traversing sideways pre-market in negative territory, but it was only just before the cash open when selling intensified as NY traders returned from the long-weekend. All sectors were red, but tech was a notable underperformer with Amazon pressuring equities after Trump’s antagonistic tweeting, while consumer discretionary was also whacked. Technical selling pressure entered after the SPX fell below its 200dma around 2590, before stabilising around 2560 (the index closes beneath its 200dma ending a 448-day run). Tesla’s woes helped dragged the Nasdaq lower, helping the Composite to join the SPX and DJIA in technical correction territory.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: A soft start to the quarter for US equities hampered sentiment in Asia as trade concerns and tech woes weighed on bourses
content:
• A soft start to the quarter for US equities hampered sentiment in Asia as trade concerns and tech woes weighed on bourses
  • In FX, USD modestly lower, RBA a non-event for AUD, EUR/USD and GBP/USD above 1.2300 and 1.4050 respectively
  • Looking ahead, highlights include Eurozone & UK PMIs, APIs and Fed’s Kashkari

ASIA

Asia stocks were mostly lower as the downbeat tone rolled over from Wall St where China’s trade retaliation and tech woes weighed heavily across all bourses, with losses in the S&P 500 (-2.2%) exacerbated on technical selling after a break below the 200DMA while the Nasdaq underperformed as it slipped into the red YTD and into correction territory. ASX 200 (+0.1%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.6%) both opened lower with the latter suffering the brunt of a firmer currency and with losses seen across tech names following similar underperformance in their US counterparts, which was led by selling in Amazon after President Trump’s tirade on the online giant. Conversely, Australian stocks then recovered as mining stocks and energy names outperformed. Hang Seng (-0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.9%) conformed to the tech-related losses and after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations for an 8th consecutive occasion, while markets in Hong Kong also took their 1st opportunity to react to China’s tariffs on US products and reports of the government pressuring banks to halt local government lending. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as they tracked the prior session’s gains in T-notes amid the risk-averse tone, while the 10yr JGB auction results were inconclusive with the results mixed as the b/c fell but accepted prices surged from prior.

Chinese Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 51.5 vs. Exp. 50.7 (Prev. 50.3). (Newswires)
Chinese Non-Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 54.6 vs. Exp. 54.5 (Prev. 54.4)
Chinese Composite PMI (Mar) 54.0 (Prev. 52.9)

Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI Final (Mar) 51.0 vs. Exp. 51.7 (Prev. 51.6). (Newswires)

Japanese Tankan Large Manufacturing Index (Q1) 24 vs. Exp. 25 (Prev. 25). (Newswires)
Japanese Tankan Large Manufacturing Outlook (Q1) 20 vs. Exp. 22 (Prev. 19)
Japanese Tankan Large All Industry Capex (Q1) 2.3% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 7.4%)


UK/EU

UK PM May is said to be planning a customs partnership as a solution for Northern Ireland in which the UK would collect tariffs and conduct import checks for the EU, although trade experts were said to be pessimistic on the proposed scheme as they viewed it as challenging and would take years to put in place. (FT)

Syed Kamall, a Conservative MEP, has accused the EU’s chief Brexit negotiator of seeking to delay the final Brexit deal so that he can be in the “limelight” when candidates are picked for the next president of the European Commission. Kamall also added that such a delay would add pressure on the UK, leaving less time to approve a deal. (Independent)

German Chancellor Merkel ally and European parliament’s Brexit steering group member Elmar Brok suggested the transition period could be prolonged if UK needs more time to prepare for its exit. (Independent)

Japan stated that a trade agreement with EU is more important than a trade deal with the UK. (Independent)

ECB’s Jazbec is to step down from position as head of Slovenia central bank to join the EU’s Single Resolution Board and will be replaced by Deputy Governor Dolenc. (Newswires)

Italy’s 5SM leader Di Maio could abandon his request for the position of PM in a political partnership with the Democratic Party. As a reminder, President Mattarella will hold talks with leaders April 4-5th. (Newswires)


FX

Price action was relatively quiet as most major pairs consolidated after yesterday’s risk-averse driven moves. As such, both EUR/USD and GBP/USD somewhat lacked vitality but were off the prior day’s lows in which EUR/USD just about reclaimed the 1.2300 handle, while USD/JPY also attempted to recover from some of the safe-haven flows which dragged the pair below the 106.00 handle. Elsewhere, CAD and MXN were supported on news that US President Trump was said to push for a NAFTA deal 'in principle' within a fortnight and antipodeans also advanced in which AUD outperformed its counterpart across the Tasman after AUD/NZD rebounded from support at around 1.0600, while the RBA decision to keep rates unchanged was a non-event given that expectations were unanimous for no policy changes and as the bank stuck to reiterations in its statement.

RBA kept the Cash Rate Target unchanged at 1.50% as expected and reiterated that steady policy is consistent with growth and inflation goals. RBA also repeated that a strengthening currency would result to slower pace of economic pick-up but that the currency remains in the range seen prior years, while it also commented that inflation likely to stay low for some time. (Newswires)


COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed overnight with WTI crude futures languishing following the prior day’s near-3% drop alongside a broad risk-averse tone and reports that Russia reported March output rose to 10.97mln BPD vs. February’s 10.95mln, which makes Russia the world’s largest crude producer. Elsewhere, gold prices slightly pulled back from yesterday’s safe-haven advances, while copper was buoyed alongside s rebound in Shanghai metal prices.  
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US and South Korea began scaled down annual military exercises, while there was no reported response from North Korea to the drills. (Newswires)

North Korea Leader Kim attended a K-Pop concert in Pyongyang which was the first time a North Korean leader attended a performance by a South Korean artistic group and which took part ahead of an anticipated meeting between the nations’ leaders. (BBC)


US

The TPLEX begins the new month/quarter bid, with the complex fulfilling its role as a safe-haven amid the stock slide. But it is worth keeping these moves in context; volume was naturally thinner in holiday trading conditions, and T-Note futures settle a mere four ticks higher (despite 10-year yields falling to 2.7170%, the lowest since early February. Major curve spreads saw only modest flattening (between 0.5bps to 2bps), and in the pre-market – before the stocks’ slide – the curve was bear-steepening. US 10-Year T-Note futures settled 4 ticks higher at 121-08+.

China imposed tariffs of between 15% and 25% on imports of 128 different products from the US including pork, nuts, wine and fruits as a response to the US tariffs on steel and aluminium. In addition, there were reports from Chinese state media that China is said to plan further trade retaliations if the US acts obstinately, while the China Ambassador to US also said China will retaliate to any new US tariffs at equal strength, with the same value and scale. (Newswires/Twitter)

White House Trade Adviser Navarro said markets should relax and that the economy is performing well, while also stated they need to be hopeful regarding NAFTA negotiations. Furthermore, Navarro added that China is stealing US stuff but does not believe US and China will pursue an ' action-response' escalation of trade dispute. (Newswires)

US President Trump said to push for a NAFTA deal 'in principle' within a fortnight, while there were also reports of speculation that a NAFTA deal could be announced at the Summits of Americas on April 13th-14th. (Newswires)

US White House is said to be looking into a long-shot plan to reduce spending from the USD 1.3tln budget bill that was passed last month. (Washington Post)

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE:  Wall St tech woes and trade war concerns saw Asia stocks reel
content:
Asia stocks are lower across the board as the downbeat tone rolls over from Wall St where China’s trade retaliation and tech woes weighed heavily across all bourses, with losses in S&P 500 exacerbated on technical selling after a break below the 200DMA while the Nasdaq underperformed as it slipped into the red YTD and into correction territory. ASX 200 (Unch) and Nikkei 225 (-0.8%) are subdued with the latter suffering the brunt of a firmer currency and with losses seen across tech names following similar underperformance in their US counterparts, which was led by selling in Amazon after President Trump’s tirade on the online giant. Conversely, Australian energy names have shrugged off the losses in crude prices and outperform, with gains led by a near 20% surge in Santos shares after it was approached with an offer that was at a 28% premium to the prior day’s close. Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.0%) also conform to the tech-related losses and after the PBoC refrained from liquidity operations for an 8th consecutive occasion, while markets in Hong Kong also take their 1st opportunity to react to China’s tariffs on US products and reports of the government pressuring banks to halt local government lending.

In FX markets, price action is relatively quiet with most major pairs consolidating after yesterday’s risk-averse driven moves. As such, both EUR/USD and GBP/USD lack vitality but are off the prior day’s lows with EUR/USD just about reclaiming the 1.2300 handle, while USD/JPY also tepidly attempts to recover from some of the safe-haven flows which dragged the pair below the 106.00 handle. Elsewhere, CAD and MXN were supported on news that US President Trump was said to push for a NAFTA deal 'in principle' within a fortnight, while antipodeans are mixed ahead of the RBA decision with AUD outperforming its counterpart across the Tasman after AUD/NZD rebounds from support at around 1.0600 and as NZD/USD homes in on the 0.7200 level to the downside.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher as they track the prior session’s gains in T-notes amid the risk-averse tone, while focus shifts to the 10yr JGB auction results later.

Preview: RBA expected to keep rates on hold in policy announcement due at 0530BST/2330CDT/1230HKT
content:
The latest RBA rate decision is due later in which consensus remains for the central bank to keep policy unchanged with ASX 30-Day Interbank Cash Rate Futures pricing in 100% expectations for the Official Cash Rate target to be kept at the record low 1.50%. Furthermore, the associated implied yield curve currently suggests March 2019 as the earliest date for a possible hike, while a recent survey also showed that respondents viewed rates to be kept unchanged throughout this year, but that median forecasts are for a total 50bps increase to 2.00% by end-September next year.

The rhetoric since the last meeting continues to suggest the unlikelihood of any near-term changes to policy with RBA Governor Lowe repeating that the likely next move in rates will be up not down, although he does not see a case for a near term adjustment of monetary policy. In addition, Lowe also stated that the central scenario is that rates will increase, but it is not inevitable and would depend on how quick unemployment could be lowered. The RBA's statement and minutes from the March meeting have also been reiterations in which the central bank stated it judged policy was consistent in reaching its targets and although the RBA noted the adverse impact of a stronger currency on the economy, it continued to suggest a lack of urgency regarding the current level.

Likewise, the data also hints that the RBA won't be in any hurry to adjust policy given the recent mixed releases including GDP for Q4 which missed expectations Y/Y but included upward revisions to the prior. The most recent jobs data was similarly inconclusive with lower than expected headline Employment Change counterbalanced as the addition to jobs was solely fuelled by Full-Time Employment and although there was a surprise increase to the Unemployment Rate, this was due to a higher Participation Rate.

Today’s meeting is scheduled for 0530BST/2330CDT/1230HKT and is not expected to trigger any significant price action, considering that the central bank’s decisions have been somewhat of a formality and with the central bank likely to reiterate the usual comments which it has been doing so for quite some time now.
